title: idolatry
comment: The worship or adoration of anyone or anything other than the LORD God. Idolatry includes the worship of other gods, such as those of the nations surrounding Israel, images or idols and the creation itself.

children.title: idolatry, in OT
children.comment: Scripture provides illustrations of idolatry from various periods in the history of the people of God. Idolatry is seen as a constant temptation for believers, especially in times of national or personal stress.

seealsos.comment: these household gods may have been either masks or statuettes

children.title: In the period of the judges

seealsos.comment: The golden calves were perhaps pedestals on which the LORD was thought to sit.

primaryrefs.comment: An Asherah pole was probably a crude carved wooden image of a Canaanite fertility goddess.

children.title: The superstitious use of religious symbols

seealsos.comment: The ephod was a priestly garment sometimes subject to excessive veneration.

children.title: idolatry, in NT
children.comment: The NT world included many religions which promoted the worship of idols. Idolatry was thus of continuing importance to NT writers, especially Paul.

children.title: Idolatry leads to other sinful behaviour

primaryrefs.comment: Verses 22 and 24-25 show the link between idolatry and immoral conduct.

children.title: Idolatry is an offence against the doctrine of creation

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ opposes the hypocrisy which objected to Roman coinage as idolatrous on the grounds that the emperor's head infringed the Ten Commandments

children.title: Demonic powers are involved with idolatry

primaryrefs.comment: ``idols'' here may well refer to a wide range of God-substitutes.

children.title: The temptations of Jesus Christ present three main kinds of spiritual idolatry
idolatry, objections to
children.comment: Scripture presents idolatry as absurd and irrational, offensive to God and a source of spiritual and moral danger.

children.title: Bowing down to idols is inappropriate

primaryrefs.comment: Two terms, that is ``idols'' and ``vile images'', meaning ``abomination'' are found here in parallel. A third, punning on the word for ``dung'' is often used by Ezekiel for idols.

children.title: Pressure to worship idols must be resisted and idols abandoned
